feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 30 at 10:55AM PDT until March 31 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Snow accumulations of 12 to 24 inches above 6000 feet (except locally up to 30 inches in the eastern San Gabriels), 6-14 inches between 5000 and 6000 feet, and 2 to 6 inches between 4500 and 5000 feet. Damaging winds gusting as high as 50 mph.
* WHERE...Interstate 5 Corridor, Western San Gabriel Mountains and Highway 14 Corridor and Eastern San Gabriel Mountains.
* WHEN...Until 11 PM PDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches and powerlines.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...There will be significant avalanche danger for the higher portions of the San Gabriels due to the strong wind and heavy snow threats. At this time, significant snow is not likely at I-5 Tejon Pass, with a 20 percent chance of a dusting to 1 inch accumulation.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Interstate 5 Corridor; Western San Gabriel Mountains and Highway 14 Corridor; Eastern San Gabriel Mountains

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 PM PDT SUNDAY

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued March 30 at 1:32PM EDT until March 30 at 5:00PM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Northwest winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph.
* WHERE...Northwest Aroostook, Northeast Aroostook, Northern Penobscot and Southeast Aroostook Counties.
* WHEN...Until 5 PM EDT this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree limbs could be blown down due to heavy wet snow covered limbs and cause additional power outages.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 31 at 3:27AM ChST until March 31 at 7:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
...GUSTY WINDS AND DRY VEGETATION WILL RESULT IN A HIGH FIRE THREAT...
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING THROUGH TUESDAY AFTERNOON...
* WIND...East wind 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 35 mph over higher terrain.
* HUMIDITY...45 to 60 percent, especially from late morning through sunset.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended. Conditions will ease during the nighttime hours, then return during the daytime.

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM CHST THIS EVENING FOR EXTREME FIRE WEATHER DANGER

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued March 30 at 9:59AM PDT until March 30 at 11:58AM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of Southwest California, including the following counties, Riverside and San Bernardino and the Inland Empire-.
* WHEN...Until 1158 AM PDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways. Overflowing poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 959 AM PDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 0.5 and 0.75 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 0.75 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include...Riverside, San Bernardino, Fontana, Moreno Valley, Ontario, Corona, Temecula, Rialto, Chino and Redlands. - https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1158 AM PDT THIS MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 30 at 12:55PM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Maine...
Mattawamkeag River At Mattawamkeag affecting Aroostook and Penobscot Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Mattawamkeag River at Mattawamkeag.
* WHEN...From late tonight until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, River approaches bankfull. At 13.5 feet, Minor lowland flooding occurs near River Road and Mattawamkeag Wilderness Park Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:30 PM EDT Saturday the stage was 12.9 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to a crest of 13.6 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 13.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 13.2 feet on 11/19/2006. - For flood safety visit http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued March 30 at 12:44PM EDT until March 30 at 5:45PM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Small stream flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues.
* WHERE...A portion of East Central Maine, including the following county, Penobscot.
* WHEN...Until 545 PM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding along the Kenduskeag Stream from East Corinth to Six Mile Falls in Bangor.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1242 PM EDT, previous rainfall and snowmelt is causing rapid rises of streams and creeks. This will cause minor flooding of the Kenduskeag Stream from East Corinth to Six Mile Falls in Bangor. - The Kenduskeag Stream gage at Six Mile Falls reported 11.13ft at 12:15PM EDT. The stream begins to flood at 11 feet. At 11ft minor flooding occurs in the low-lying properties in the Six Mile Falls area of Bangor near Route 15 and 221. Additional, flooding of low-lying areas upstream to East Corinth occurs above 11 feet. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Bangor, Corinth, Kenduskeag, Glenburn and Levant. - For flood safety visit http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 545 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued March 30 at 9:33AM PDT until March 30 at 11:30AM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
FFWSGX
The National Weather Service in San Diego has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Southwestern San Diego County in southwestern California...
* Until 1130 AM PDT.
* At 933 AM PDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain across the warned area. Between 0.25 and 0.75 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 0.5 to 1 inch in 45 to 60 minutes. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Heavy rain producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...Chula Vista, San Diego, La Jolla, El Cajon, Encinitas, National City, La Mesa, Poway, Imperial Beach, Ramona, Coronado and Tierrasanta.

cap:parameter.value: NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 11:30 AM PDT. Avoid flooded areas.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 11:30 AM PDT. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 30 at 12:02PM EDT by NWS Charleston WV
entry.summary:
A combination of recent dry weather and winds gusting between 15 to 20 mph will increase the danger of fire start and spread this afternoon and evening.
Please exercise caution if handling open flames or equipment that creates sparks. Dispose of cigarette buttes, matches, and other flammable materials in appropriate containers. Keep vehicles off of dry grass and obey local burn bans. Most dry grasses, dead leaves, and other tree litter could easily ignite and spread fire quickly.
Virginia law prohibits burning in the spring from midnight to 4 PM...February 15th through April 30th. Evening burning is highly discouraged at this time due to the risk of holdover embers heading into today.

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED FIRE DANGER THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 30 at 9:54AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
Patchy dense freezing fog is currently being observed over portions of central Montana and along the Rocky Mountain front. Visibility reductions down to less than half a mile are possible through at least the early afternoon. Light freezing drizzle may accompany the fog, possibly accumulating up to a glaze of ice on exposed surfaces.
Travelers and pedestrians should be prepared for highly variable road conditions, including sudden drops in visibility below a half mile and slippery roads and sidewalks. Be extra careful on elevated surfaces such as bridges and decks that are prone to freezing. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 30 at 11:08AM EDT by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
Afternoon relative humidity values are expected to drop below 35 percent across the entire forecast area, and below 30 percent for much of the Tennessee valley and far western North Carolina, again this afternoon. In addition to the low humidity values, gusty winds will be possible area wide this afternoon as well, with gusts of 20 to 25 mph being common place. Some higher gusts will be possible mainly north of I-40 and along or east of the I-81 corridor as well. As such, fire danger levels will be elevated this afternoon through the early evening hours.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities whether you may burn outdoors. If you do burn outside, use extreme caution.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 30 at 9:53AM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
entry.summary:
Dry and windy conditions are expected again today across the mountains into the foothills of North Carolina, as well as the mountains and Piedmont of Virginia. Relative humidity values will drop to under 30 percent this afternoon. West to southwest winds of 10 to 20 mph, with gusts of 20 to 35 mph will accompany this dry airmass. This will result in the continued rapid drying of leaf litter and other forest fuels.
Residents and visitors are urged to exercise caution if handling open flames or equipment that creates sparks. Also, dispose of cigarette butts, matches, and other flammable items in appropriate containers. Keep vehicles off of dry grass and obey local burn bans. Most dry grasses, dead leaves, and other tree litter could easily ignite and spread fire quickly.
For more information about wildfire danger, burn restrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit your state's forestry or environmental protection website.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 30 at 9:49AM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
The combination of low relative humidity values between 20 and 30 percent, southwest winds gusting to 20 to 25 mph, and drying fuels will result in increased fire danger for portions of central and south central Virginia.
Residents are urged to exercise caution handling any potential ignition source...including machinery...cigarettes...and matches. Be sure to properly discard all smoking materials. Any dry grasses and tree litter that ignite will have the potential to spread quickly.
Virginia residents are reminded that open-air burning is prohibited before 4 pm each day through April 30th.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 30 at 4:07AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: A strong storm moving across the Alaska Range on Saturday night will produce seasonably strong winds across the Interior, including into the Fairbanks area. Temps will warm back up into the 40s and upper 30s by Saturday afternoon, with a chance for mixed precipitation (rain and snow) Saturday evening and overnight. The warm front will lift north and a cold front surging through from the west will turn any mixed precipitation to snow showers, along with very blustery winds from the southwest, by Sunday morning. Around the Fairbanks area, expect west winds 15 to 30 mph Sunday morning into early Sunday evening, with gusts to 35 mph across higher elevation hills. Snow amounts will be 2 to 3 inches over higher terrain, with the possibility of 1 to 2 inches of wind driven snowfall over the lower elevations through Sunday night.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fortymile Country; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana

cap:parameter.value: Strong Low to Bring Blustery winds, Mixed Precipitation, and Snow to the Tanana Valley, Fortymile, and Upper Chena Basin Late Saturday and Sunday

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 30 at 3:33AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
Dry air and deep mixing will allow the relative humidity to fall to critical values across northeast Georgia and western North Carolina this afternoon. Relative Humidity values are expected to be 25 percent or less for several hours this afternoon through early evening. Southwest winds will be 10 to 15 MPH, with gusts of 15 to 25 MPH. This combined with dry fuels will result in potentially dangerous fire weather conditions.
Refer to your local burn-permitting agency to determine whether you may burn today. If you do burn, exercise extreme caution.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 29 at 1:56PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: A strong low pressure system moving across the Alaska Range on Saturday will bring strong winds to the Alaska Range and around the Delta Junction area. Temps will warm back up into the 40s across the Central Interior on Saturday. As the chinook flow weakens we expect temperatures to drop and snow to develop across the Central Interior late Saturday night into Sunday afternoon. The heaviest snow expected will be west and north of Fairbanks. Fairbanks could still see 1 to 2 inches on Sunday. Also we expect strong winds gusting to 35 mph over the higher terrain producing blowing snow and low visibility along the Steese, Elliott and Dalton Highways late Saturday night into Sunday. Around the Fairbanks area, expecting west winds 15 to 30 mph Sunday morning into Sunday afternoon.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 29 at 1:16PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: A strong low pressure system moving across the Alaska Range on Saturday will bring strong winds to the Alaska Range and around the Delta Junction area. Temps will warm back up into the 40s across the Central Interior on Saturday. As the chinook flow weakens we expect temperatures to drop and snow to develop across the Central Interior late Saturday night into Sunday afternoon. The heaviest snow expected will be west and north of Fairbanks. Fairbanks could still see 1 to 2 inches on Sunday. Also we expect strong winds gusting to 35 mph over the higher terrain producing blowing snow and low visibility along the Steese, Elliott and Dalton Highways late Saturday night into Sunday. Around the Fairbanks area, expecting west winds 15 to 25 mph Sunday morning into Sunday afternoon.
